#Text=Belize

#Text=Belize , formerly British Honduras , is the only country in Central America without a coastline on the Pacific Ocean ( only the Caribbean Sea to its east ) and the only one in the region with English as its official language .
#Text=Belize is bordered by Guatemala to the west and south , and Mexico to the north .
#Text=Cities
#Text=- Inland capital
#Text=- Belize 's largest city , on the Caribbean Sea
#Text=- Large Garifuna town in the south , formerly known as Stann Creek Town
#Text=- Garifuna village
#Text=- Beautiful , quiet port town in the South ; home to a complex and diverse Amerindian market on the weekends
#Text=- Known as Cayo to locals , Maya and Hispanic influence near the Guatemala border
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=- large barrier island in the north
#Text=- smaller barrier island in the north
#Text=- long peninsula ( almost an island ) off Stann Creek
#Text=Maya ruins
#Text=Understand

#Text=With its British colonial history and a long Caribbean coast , Belize is culturally similar to many of Britain 's former West Indian island colonies , with a majority creole or Afro-Caribbean population .
#Text=But it also includes a large native Mayan population , especially in the north and northwest of the country .
#Text=As a result , although English is the official language , Spanish is also often spoken .
#Text=In the south east along the Caribbean coast live the Garifuna ( Black Caribs ) , an Afro-Amerindian culture .

#Text=After long journeys starting in what is now the Netherlands in 1790 , via Germany , Southern Russia , Canada , the United States , and Mexico , several thousand German-speaking Mennonite Christians arrived in Belize in 1958 after long and detailed discussions with the government regarding specific exemptions and privileges .
#Text=They are easily recognizable by their speech ( somewhat distinctive from modern standard German ) and " quaint " dress .

#Text=World class attractions include exploring the lush jungles with exotic plants and animals , deep sea fishing , swimming , snorkeling and diving in the Caribbean Sea with its attractive reefs , and visiting the Mayan ruins .
#Text=Income levels are still very low and the infrastructure is very basic .
#Text=The Belizeans are very proud and friendly to visitors and the tourist industry grew greatly in the last decade .
#Text=History
#Text=Like the neighbouring parts of Guatemala and Mexico , this area was settled for thousands of years by the Maya people .
#Text=They are still here , an important part of Belize 's people and culture .
#Text=While the Spanish Empire claimed the area in the 16th century , the Spanish made little progress in settling here .
#Text=The British settled first on the coast and offshore islands for logging .
#Text=In 1798 British Belizean forces defeated a Spanish attempt to drive them out in the Battle of St. George 's Caye , an anniversary still celebrated as a holiday each 10 September .
#Text=The colony of British Honduras grew in the 19th century .
#Text=At first Africans were brought in as slaves , but slavery was abolished here in 1838 .

#Text=Following the abolition of slavery , the British would bring indentured India n labourers to the colony to supplement the labour pool , and their descendants remain a significant minority to this day .
#Text=Many refugees from the 19th-century Caste War of Yucatán Peninsula escaped the conflict to settle in Belize , especially the northern section .
#Text=The government of Guatemala has long claimed to have inherited the 15th-century Spanish claim to Belize .

#Text=Although the British were willing to grant independence to British Honduras as early as the mid-1960s , this ongoing dispute played a major role in delaying full Belizean independence until 1981 , long after London granted independence to other former colonies in the region .
#Text=Guatemala refused to recognize an independent Belize at all until 1991 , and to this day lays claim to virtually all Belizean territory south of Belize City .
#Text=The topic remains a sensitive one , particularly in the southern half of Belize .
#Text=Belize escaped the bloody civil conflicts of the 1980s that engulfed much of Central America , and refugees from the conflict in Guatemala arrived , mostly settling in the west .
#Text=While Belize has not been immune to the rampant drug crime and grinding poverty of its neighbours it is a comparatively safe destination in a conflict-prone part of the world .
#Text=Belize shares particularly close diplomatic and economic ties with both the United Kingdom and the United States .
#Text=Tourism has become the mainstay of the economy as the old agricultural products — sugar , banana , and oranges — have lost ground .
#Text=The country remains plagued by high unemployment , growing involvement in the South American drug trade , and increased urban crime .
#Text=In 2006 commercial quantities of oil were discovered in the Spanish Lookout area .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Tropical , very hot and humid .
#Text=The dry season typically lasts from February to May and then the rainy season typically lasts through to November .
#Text=Hurricanes that bring coastal flooding , especially in the south , are prevalent from June to November .
#Text=Terrain
#Text=The flat coastal plain is swampy with low mountains in the south .
#Text=The highest point is Victoria Peak at 1,160 m.
#Text=Talk
#Text=As a former British colony , the official language of Belize is standard English with UK spelling rules , which makes Belize stand out from its Spanish-speaking neighbours .
#Text=Spanish , Garifuna ( Carib ) and the Maya languages/dialects of Kekchi , Mopan and Yucatec are spoken in various parts of the country .
#Text=Spanish is widely used as the first language in northern and western parts of the country .
#Text=So-called " kitchen Spanish , " an amalgam of Spanish and English , is common on Ambergris Caye .
#Text=Belizean Creole , which has a certain degree of mutual intelligibility with standard English , is widely spoken as well .
#Text=Most Belizeans are proficient in English and at least one of these other languages .
#Text=Many Belizeans speak a mix of Creole and English among friends , and standard English to foreigners .
#Text=The strong Caribbean accent may take some getting used to .
#Text=Entry requirements
#Text=All visitors are required to have sufficient funds , US$ 75 per day , and documents required for their next destination .

#Text=If entering by land from Mexico , you will be charged a fee of M$ 533 ( Mexican pesos ) ( as of May 2018 ) by Mexican immigration unless you can show proof that you paid the immigration fee when you entered Mexico .
#Text=Your FMM tourist card is not enough .
#Text=If you crossed at a land border , you 'll need the actual receipt from when you paid the fee .
#Text=If you reached Mexico via a commercial flight , you 've may have already paid the fee with your airfare , but the border guards here do not care .
#Text=You might be able to convince them if you have a print-out of an itemized receipt from the airline showing that this specific fee was included .
